remixed_from.author: MoonCactus
remixed_from.title: The banana XY bushing block and belt tensioner. Drop in replacement for the ultimaker

description.text: This is an alternative arrangement for positioning and adjusting the Z-stop on a QU-BD RXL 3-D printer. Update: 01/03/14: I added two new STL's for the bottom piece that move the adjustment screw 1mm closer to the bed, since some users reported problems with the alignment on their printers. Update: 10/27/13: I replaced the STL files with lower-res versions, oriented to lie flat in the X/Y plane for easier slicing and printing. I found that the homing repeatability on my RXL printer was very poor, with a variability of at least 0.5mm, which I attributed in part to the very obvious flex in the corner of the frame that held the bed. Furthermore, the tight positioning of the Z end-stop switch behind the front right frame pillar made it very difficult to adjust the z=0 position. To fix this, I decided to move the z-stop over by the Z-axis, where the stability of the platform is maximized, and use an easily adjusted screw to trigger it. I needed to keep the assembly as rigid and firmly fixed as possible, so I added a built-in 'banana block' clamp (inspired by Jeremie Francois' design for sliding blocks that I am using on my Ultimaker). With this in place, I am getting perfect z-homing every time, compared to the the 20% or less first-layer success rate I was seeing originally.

This is a relatively drastic modification to the homing system on the RXL printer, and requires relocating and resoldering the microswitch that sets the home position. If you do this then, of course, you do so at your own risk. YMMV, but I'm finding that this modification has dramatically improved the reliability and quality of my prints. I actually printed these parts in PLA on my Ultimaker, because getting decent quality prints without a decent Z-stop solution was such a pain on my QU-BD printer. :-) I used a 0.15mm layer height. Using this design requires removing the existing z-stop from its position behind the front right frame pillar, cutting the wires, and soldering in longer wires, to allow it to be located adjacent to the right-side z-screw. In order to get at the original switch, you need to remove the two screws in the top, front right corner of the printer, adjacent to the Y motor. Those allow you to remove the bracket that holds the motor in place, exposing the Y and Z switches. Remove the Z-switch, in order to relocate it, and solder some longer wires in place to connect to the switch in it's new location. I found it useful to reinsert a screw into one of the nuts that had previously held the z-switch in place, and then use a cable tie to anchor the wiring to that screw, in order to keep it from fouling on the belt and pulley assembly in that corner. I included photos showing the cable-tied wires in the corner beside the pulley, and routed along the edge of the printer - again using cable ties to keep them in place. You need to tighten the ties closely, as there is not much clearance between the rail and the print head assembly as it slides from front to back. The two printed parts of this assembly are designed to use 12mm, flat-head M2 machine screws with corresponding hex nuts fitted into the recesses to assemble the components, and a single 30mm M3 screw to activate the switch. If the tolerances are a bit tight to fit the nuts, you can try chilling the nuts (e.g., with liquid air from a spray duster can - be careful, it's really cold!) or by heating the nut to soften the plastic locally - and then perhaps judiciously applying some force with a vice/hammer. :-) The lower piece clamps over one of the screws that holds the bushing for the Z axis, and fits tight up against the edge of the bed to minimize movement. The M3 screw that adjusts the home position is held in place by two nuts - one a regular hex nut (which also helps to locate the two pieces relative to one another), and the other a nyloc nut to reduce any tendency of the screw to shake out of position over time. A cross sectional drawing shows the positions of the bolt and nuts that you need to add. I included two different versions of the lower STL's. For my printer, the original version was fine, but some users reported that that put the screw slightly too far away from the switch, so I added a '1mm closer' variant. The upper piece fits around the upper frame rail adjacent to the z-screw. The z-switch is located in the lower part, slightly recessed to avoid accidentally triggering it. You need to carefully remove the roller actuator lever on the switch, so that the button is directly available to make contact with the M3 bolt that sticks up from the lower piece. Once it has been lined up so that the M3 screw sticking up will engage the button on the switch, it can be locked in place by tightening the screw in the back edge of the upper block. This bolt passes through a hex nut that you need to insert inside the block, and then presses on the back of a 'banana block'. As you tighten the screw, the other end of the sliding block presses on the underside of the rail, locking the block in place. Another cross-sectional drawing shows the position of the M2 tensioning bolt, and the required nut. To zero the bed, back the long M3 screw out a few millimeters. Heat the head and bed to your normal operating temperatures, and ensure that the extruder assembly is pushed down and seated properly on the x-carriage (it is only secured in one corner and can twist up, if the nozzle has previously crashed into the bed). Use an interface program like Repetier Host to move the head to the center of the bed, and then slowly move the bed up, until it just touches the tip of the nozzle. You can see how close the head is getting by looking carefully along the surface of the bed, and watching the distance between the tip of the nozzle, and its reflection in the shiny surface of the basalt. Once the nozzle is just touching the bed, slowly tighten the M3 screw until you just hear the switch click. Check that the screw tip properly engages the switch button fully, and that the screw doesn't catch on any part of the housing, or have any risk of moving to slip off the button. Adjust the position of the parts if needed, and make sure everything is locked solidly in place, and won't move. Use Repetier etc to move the bed back down 10mm, and then click the button to home the z-axis. Watch and listen for the click, and make sure that the bed comes to rest just touching the print head without causing the latter to rotate upwards. Repeat and adjust the M3 screw as needed. Once you have the z=0 position set in the center of the bed, then you can drop the bed 10mm and move the head to each corner of the bed. At each one, click to re-home the z-axis, and make sure that the bed comes to a stop with the nozzle tip just barely touching, and without the bed having caused the head to rotate out of its lowest position. If needed, you can insert screws in the bed frame, in each corner of the basalt bed (from underneath), and use those to adjust the height of the bed at each corner. If any changes are needed, repeat the leveling/homing exercise from scratch, until the z-switch triggers with the nozzle tip just touching the bed in the middle of the bed, and at all four corners. I designed this part using SpaceClaim, and have included the native files. I also exported it as STEP files, incase those are more useful for adjustment in other packages.

description.text:
I decided to upgrade my E3D Chimera to PT100 temperature sensors as E3D have moved away from thermistos and will only be suppling cartridge type sensors in the future.

Part of the PT100 sensor setup is an amplifier board which is supplied as a fully populated PCB without any protection from shorting against any metal parts of the printer.

I have two designs so that it can be used inline in a wiring harness or fixed to 2020 (or bigger) aluminium extrusion. Both designs have recesses for M3 screw heads and nuts as shown in the second photo.

Dimensions were taken from the E3D drawing. I have also included the Autodesk 123 Design files for those who might be interested.

http://e3d-online.com/Kits-and-Multipacks/V6-PT100-Sensor-Kit

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci Duo 2.0a

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm

20%

Notes:

This design can be printed without support as there is a thin layer at the point where any change of hole diameter occurs.

description.text:
I'm working on labelled keys, it may ask moderate modification to my design, i hope it won't be too long, stay tuned!

FRENCH:

J'ai reçu mon PocketChip (d'une campagne kickstarter) et même si le clavier de la bête est utilisable, j'ai décidé de faire un ajout afin de l'améliorer un peu. Donc le voici, il est fait en deux pièces qui "s'assemblent" et qui viennent se glisser au dessus du clavier d'origine. J'en ai fait deux différents, l'un avec des touches en polyflex, assez "serré", ce qui a pour effet de supprimer le côté sec des touches (ceux qui en on un savent de quoi je parle). Niveau feeling c'est plutôt sympa et ça apporte un réel plus quand il s'agit de jouer.

Le second est fait entièrement en PLA normal, les touches conservent le côté sec et pour jouer c'est pour le coup encore mieux qu'avec le polyflex.

L'avantage de ce design est qu'il n'impose pas un démontage du PocketChip pour être installé. Ce qui permet de prévoir d'autres designs pour différents usage (à déterminer) et de changer de clavier rapidement.

Vous pourriez rencontrer un manque "d'efficacité" sur certaines touches. Me concernant, la touche C à un peu de mal a s'exprimer quand j'appuie dessus, je suis obligé d'appuyer un peu plus fort dessus pour qu'elle fonctionne à chaque fois. Ça peut vous arrivez ou pas, sur une ou deux touches, cela semble aléatoire.

Edit: J'ai fais la feuille à coller sur le clavier afin de pouvoir l'utiliser aisément. Mine de rien, savoir à quoi correspondent les touches ça peut être utile... C'est pas magnifique, mais je suis plus à l'aise avec freecad qu'avec gimp.

Ajout: J'ai fait en plus un stylet à clipser sur le pocket chip! Ça pourrait peut-être gêner l'utilisation des connecteurs GPIO. Si jamais c'est le cas, dites le moi, j'adapterai le design. Vous aurez un peu de mal à le mettre en place et à le retirer au début. Mais au bout de quelques mises en place/retrait, ça ira déjà beaucoup mieux.

Si vous avez des soucis pour slicer le stylet avec Simplify 3D, voici la marche à suivre:
1) Repair-->Identify Self-Intersecting Surfaces
2) Mesh-->Separate Connected Surfaces

Merci à TheClockworkCoder pour l'astuce!

Si vous avez des suggestions d'améliorations n'hésitez pas.

ENGLISH:

I received my pocket chip few weeks ago (from a kickstarter campaign) and even if the keyboard of the beast is usable, i decided to make an add-on to it in order to make it a little bit better. Here it is, there's to piece to "assemble", and they slide over the original keyboard. There's 2 different type, one with polyflex keys, which is a bit tight, which have as effect tu suppress the "clickyness" of the keyboard (the ones who owns a Pocketchip knows). The feling is quite good and bring a reel convinience when it comes to games.

The second one is entirely made of normal PLA, the keys keep the clicky feeling and it
is even better when playing than the polyflex.

The main advantage of this design is that don't require to dismount the PocketChip to install it. It allows to provide other designs for other use (to determine) and to change the keyboard quickly.

You may encounter a lack of "effectiveness" on some keys. For me, the C key struggle a little bit when i press on it, i have to press it more firmly to have it working each time. It can happen to you or not, on one or two keys, it seems aleatory.

Edit: I've made the sheet to print and paste on the keyboard. It could be useful to know what the keys are assigned to. It's not wonderful, but i have more ease with freecad than gimp.

Add: I've made a stylus pen to put on the pocketchip! It may bother the GPIO pins use. If it's the case, tell me, i'll change the design. It may also be a bit difficult to place end remove it. But after few placement/removal, it'll be better.

If you have a problem with Simplify 3D to slice the stylus, follow these 2 steps:
1) Repair-->Identify Self-Intersecting Surfaces
2) Mesh-->Separate Connected Surfaces

Thanks to the ClockWorkCoder for the tips!

If you have suggestion in order to improve it, don't hesitate.

Printer:

Dagoma Discovery 200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200µm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

FR: Comme les pièces sont plates et les touches étroites, ils n'ont pas réellement besoin de remplissage. Concernant le polyflex, veillez à avoir au moins 25% de remplissage, j'ai eu un petit soucis sur la touche espace. Les motifs de remplissages ne sont pas bien répartis et je n'ai qu'un côté de la touche espace qui fonctionne. L'autre est creux et ne fonctionne pas quand j'appuie dessus.

----------- EN: As the pieces are flat and the key quite narrow, they don't really need infill. Concerning the polyflex part, you should at least put 25% infill, i had a "problem" on the space key, one half had enoug infill the other don't. So the space bar only work on one half, the other one is to soft (it's hollow) and don't work.

Coller la feuille et percez là - Paste the sheet of paper and pierce it.

Lien vers le fichier à imprimer - Link to the file to print : https://www.flickr.com/gp/paratyphi/uL22B5

J'ai utilisé ça http://www.prittworld.fr/fr/prittworld/parents/produits/coller/roller-colle-compact-pritt.html pour coller la feuille. Ça évite d'avoir des gros paquets de colle, c'est pas la solution parfaite, la meilleure aurait été d'utiliser des feuilles adhésives. En tout cas, quand c'est en place, arrive la partie amusante qui consiste à percer les trous. J'ai fait ça avec un cutter et le résultat et pas trop mal. J'aurai pu faire des petits cercles qui auraient été percé avec une perforatrice, mais ça aurait été long à faire sur gimp. Je suis un peu fainéant.

I used this http://www.prittworld.fr/fr/prittworld/parents/produits/coller/roller-colle-compact-pritt.html to paste the sheet. It help to avoid big patch of glue, it's not a perfect solution, the best would be to use adhesive sheet of paper. Anyway, when it's in place here comes the fun part which consist to pierce the holes. I have made this with a cutter and the result isn't that bad. I could have put little circle to pierce with a punch holder but it'll be a bit long on gimp. I'm a lazy man.

Those normal hotshoe mounts that come with the DSLR are so boring! That's why I made this to make your DSLR cooler!

Is the new version of the G&C printer. The first version was called Good & Cheap printer, in this new model the "cheap" part is lost and you replace the "good" with a "very good". Building this printer from scratch will cost between 800€ to 1200€, depending of some hardware's options chosen.

Main modifications is relation to the first model:
-There is no printed parts that could affect the rigidity of the frame or linear movements.
-3 plates in the dxf files must be laser cut with 5mm aluminium.
-bigger print volume: 305mm x 265mm x 350mm
-All axis have better linear mechanism: it use 2 x 15mm with 330mm linear rails on the Y axis and a long 15mm with 410mm linear rail on the X. The Z bed use 2 x 16mm rods and 2 x longs linear bearing. X and Y axis is connected using 5mm aluminum plates.
-Z ball screw of 12mm, 4mm pitch. The two new bearings was the exact same size of the main bed 20x60 allowing to be easy to install and reduce problems with miss alignments.
-corexy movement compact and only in one plane, use a twisted belt in front to achieve this.

The printer was designed to be an upgrade of the g&c and it reuse a lots of the material.
The print quality is very high.

Please don't put this on a switch that may need to be turned off in an emergency!

description.text:
A simple portable Led Panel. Great for taking close up photos. The body is made of two 3d ABS printed parts and a plywood plate (mainly because I like to mix wood with other materials!). The LEDs are 5050 strips and powered by 8 AAA batteries.

Materials:

  • 3D ABS printed parts
  • 6mm plywood (164x62 mm)
  • 5050 waterproof LED strip IP68 Waterproof (45 leds)
  • 8 x M3 screws (20mm)
  • 8 x M3 nuts
  • 1 x switch (12mm)
  • 2 x Batteries Case (4xAAA)
  • 1 x 1/4"-Tripod Mount Screw Adapter to Flash

https://youtu.be/QqOwtd1gHcs

The plywood plate could be thinner or even 3D printed (alternative front included). The LED strips are connected through 1mm holes on each side (all the positives on the left and all the negatives on the right). I guess the 8 AAA batteries will be strong enough to power this panel for many hours.

description.text:
Placing multiple "big pieces" here where otherwise separate components can fit on the build plate as single pieces. There is some redesign to account for orientation and support implications, and this can only make support worse. Also of course removal of defunct pins. These are all pin and size compatible with the master design at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158120 1) A single piece design for the components backfan + BackBottom
2) A single piece design for the Rear Top + Temple
3) Combined Roof,+ Backfan + Back Bottom, on the smaller helmets this is a nice backbone to the model, it will JUST fit on a rep2 build plate with raft, and very careful rotation, placement, but it really is at the limit. Will update with image, when I successfully print or otherwise. In the original design, I was worried on size / warping / and also trying to keep pieces I might rework small. It is better now to have combined pieces where valid, as long as implications for support can be kept to a minimum.

Wanted to make sure I had no backlash so I could use auto bed levelling. I did see other options on here but was thinking this is a simple way to add it with out needing to disassemble anything.  
Have used for a few prints now and all looks good.

BOM
  • 2x 5mm nuts
  • 2x springs
  • Print this part out
    • You should be able to slip you spring and nut on with out disassembling anything, they should just fit down the hole the 5mm rod sticks out of. Tighten nut until spring is compressed to your liking then slip the printed part on to stop the nut from turning when using the printer. Depending on your spring you may need to adjust the height of the part. I used 2 spring I had on hand 3/8 x 3/4 x .032

description.text:
This is a fully parametric quick-change filament filter designed to keep dust on the filament from getting into your extruder and clogging it. This was inspired by the CreativeTools Universal Filter, but trying to shove a sponge into that closed filter didn't make sense to me. So instead I used OpenSCAD to design a two-piece threaded filter that screws together, and put slits on the side so it could be slipped onto and off of the filament without even needing to disconnect from the extruder. Then I added tabs on the side so it could still easily be unscrewed even if it ends up with a little lubricating oil on the side. After creating this I found Kezat's filter which follows the same philosophy, so I listed this as a remix since he had the idea first.

I added a 1.75mm and a 3mm version, since it is only one variable to change. I only tested the 1.75mm version, but if there are any problems with the 3mm version let me know in the comments.

It is important to select a soft sponge for inside so that it tightly wraps the filament. You then should add a little lubricating oil to the sponge before inserting it, to help it flow smoothly and grip the filament tightly. CreativeTools recommended mineral oil, but I had run out of that and found that grapeseed oil worked fine at PLA-printing temperatures. I recommend intentionally staying above the oil's smoke point if you experiment with alternates. After the first print, very little oil passes through into the print. After you have it assembled, make sure it slides freely up and down on the filament, but with an obvious grip of the sponge around the filament.

Note: The OpenSCAD file uses my threading library for the threaded rod feature that forms the basic structure of this. It is just a hollowed out threaded rod with a slit and tabs. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686322

Update 2016-07-28: My wife noted that the top and the bottom of this were not obvious during filament changes. Therefore version 2 is now labeled "IN" and "OUT" on the two sides. It makes a difference if you turn it around and push the dirt you filtered back out the input side, so this is an important distinction. Also, change your sponges once in a while if you want to see evidence that these actually work.

Update 2017-12-24: Something changed in Cura that made the connection of the external threads to the base print out much thinner than before, so version 3 has this thickened slightly.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-11

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5 x/y, 0.2 z, 1.5 perimeter, 1.0 top/bottom

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Infill does not matter much since this object is mostly perimeter anyway. But I recommend at least 2 layers for the perimeter so that the threads do not snap off if you tighten it down too tightly. I used 3 layers and 50% and found it very sturdy.

title: Replacement Rung Lock for TecTake Telescope Ladder and identical Products

description.text:
The original rung lock of the ladder has a constructional issue causing a predefined breakpoint at the begin of the lock tongues. So a lot of these locks breaks over the time and can't be bought separate.
The new designed part does not have this problem and can be used instead of buying a complete new ladder.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

75%

Notes:

Use 4 bottom layers, 6 top layers and 3 perimeter shells.

On FDM-printers it is highly recommended to print the lock in the attached two parts and in the given orientation.

If the part is printed with the tongues upward the connection of the tongues only depends of the adhesion of the separate layers causing the crack with minimal force.

If printed in the given orientation the tongues are much stronger and will not crack easy (see attached shot of the slicers result). Connect the part of the handle to the main part with some drops of super glue.
designed with FreeCAD

Why:
I tried one of the small printable quadcopters on here but the arms were constantly breaking and I couldn't get any real flight time. I live in Japan so space is a little limited. As soon as the thing starts to drift in the wind I would try to land, but since I have 0 skill I usually ended up crash landing. Then I:d have to fix it again, and I ended up flying it only 3 times in as many months. Each time it seemed to work a little better, but I finally decided I needed to design everything from scratch and prioritize durability. This is my initial result. What:
The non-printable parts (besides electronics) are: a 60mm x 60mm x 5mm aluminum block, a 1 meter T shaped aluminum rod cut into 4 equal lengths with a height of 15mm and a width of 13mm, a little double sided velcro strap, and various m2 10 and 15mm bolts and nuts. (fyi, I got all of this at Tokyu Hands) How:
The motor blocks should just slide right onto the rods, and the blocks are basically "full tang". I put a little superglue on the ends and they seem sturdy enough. I printed them solid for additional strength since I need durability more than mobility with my current flying skill. The battery tray sits over my electronics and I attached my multiwii flight controller to the raised platform in the middle of the main compartment. I put my radio, gps, and battery alarm on either side in the sunken areas. I just attached those things with a little hot glue since they're very light and hot glue sticks to PLA VERY well.
UPDATE: Be sure to rotate the motor block 90 deg so that the T slot is on the build plate. Extra info:
I tend not to design parts with predrilled holes because printers tend to make them a little bigger or smaller depending on calibration, which typically results in redrilling them anyway. Additionally I like to plan things out, but leave room for last minute changes, so if you don't have access to a drill, my design is probably not the best one for you. Also, I designed the motor blocks to take a little piece of wood between the motor and the block. My motors tend to run a little hot, and have custom axles. The wood acts as a heat buffer and I drill out a hole which allows for the slight protrusion of the axle. Finally, I designed the parts with support in the design. If you see .5mm lines/surfaces/shells, those are meant to be removed after printing. I find that simply adding the support in the design helps in two big ways, The amount of plastic needed for support is greatly reduced, and this in turn reduces print time by about 25% on the main compartment and 10% on the motor blocks. Just use a hobby knife to remove it.

comments.text: Just FYI, I flew it on the weekend and it worked beautifully. It is a little heavier than it was before, so I should probably get some larger props, but even after a few rough landings, nothing has broken. It's pretty sturdy.

title: Drop-in M4 and M5 T-slot Nuts for 80/20 Aluminum Extrusion

description.text:
This is a post-assembly drop-in style T-slot nut for 80/20 aluminum. This is the type of aluminum extrusion with 11mm width at the top of the T-slot, a 6mm wide opening, about 4mm deep in the bottom of the T portion, and another 1.8mm or so in the 6mm wide slit. The design was with OpenSCAD so it could be adjusted to other T-slot profiles. The drop-in T-slot nut is designed to be inserted into the middle of an extruded rod and rotated into place. It then catches in the perpendicular orientation.

Both M5 and M4 stl files are included. The M5 version is close to the tolerance limits of what will print well within the 6mm profile. The upper cylindrical thread extension in the M5 version is not as snug as the bottom portion because the wall is thinner, so if you tighten a bolt into just the upper cylindrical threaded portion of the M5 version you will NOT get a good grip. If you tighten through into the bottom of the T it will grip snugly. The M4 version is a little stronger in its grip because it has a higher thickness to the plastic which wraps around the bolt.

These are not as strong as metal nuts. I would not recommend suspending anything irreplaceable from one of these, but in tests of the strength limits I was able to suspend my 10kg printer (sorry printer) in the air from a single one of these nuts as long as it was screwed in all the way, and this worked fine for me. No guarantees on your print, but I think this can work for assembly. However you must be absolutely careful not to overtighten these. The leverage advantage of an Allen wrench plus the leverage advantage of threading can apply far more force than the weight of 10kg, and you will easily strip the threads.

Note: The OpenSCAD file uses my threading library for the threaded holes. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686322

Update v2 (2017-04-16): The new threads.scad update is much more economical with the threading faces. The updated v2 stl files using this are nearly equivalent but rendered more efficiently.

HICTOP 3DP-11

comments.author: Eblab

comments.text: There was a known bug in OpenSCAD 2015.03 (already fixed in 2016) where syntax error messages with include files would fail to note that it was an error in the include file.  Line 39 of T-slot_nut.scad is very simple, but it's possible you grabbed the wrong threads.scad or you accidentally inserted an extra character into one of the two files while inspecting them.  I recommend redownloading both files into a clean directory and trying again.

comments.author: federico9292

comments.text: The strips of plastic gripped by the threads on an M3 bolt are very thin, so I wouldn't recommend putting anything requiring strength on one of these with an M3 bolt.  Test carefully before trusting such a setup.  Another design with a recessed conventional metal M3 nut would probably be necessary for strength.  But sure, it's only one number to change, so I have added an stl file for this.

title: Active fume Exhaust for 3D printers (MB R2X implementation)

description.text:
Reading about ABS fumes made me worried as I share the same space with my Makerbot Replocator 2X so I designed and build this active exhaust with a fan I removed from some scraped equipment. What you'll see is the first version which is working perfectly but lacks the fineness and style which I will (maybe) do at a later stage. Nevertheless, it works fine, no smell in the office and no worries, no extra noise and no negative effect on the printer due to reduced temperature or airflow.

Within the attached files you will find my original Sketchup so you can improve and modify the parts to your needs, if you do so, please share your work and add a link to a comment on this thing.

description.text:
This hut was originally made by Primitive Technology (View it on YouTube in the link below), so I do not take credit for the actual design of the hut. However. It was still made by me. This hut would be very difficult to 3D Print, but it was very fun to design. If anyone tries to print this, however, tell me know how it turns out!

Link to original video of hut design

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nCKkHqlx9dE

This is a reshaping of Nvalencia's elegant design from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1621685

Nvalencia's box was very attractive, but it was too wide to accommodate the position of the Z-axis stop on the pillar according to the assembly instructions from HICTOP. I wrote a few small modules in OpenSCAD to crop and trim an existing stl design, and used this to reshape Nvalencia's design to be a tight horizontal fit around the circuit board. While I was doing this I also fixed the thin-backplate error on the lettering so that it came out with the intended indentation effect.

This was my first attempt at modifying an existing stl file using OpenSCAD, and I found it a little easier than I anticipated it being.

Nice job!!!! just wonder if temperature around the mother board is an issue or not...
is it working ok? no extra fan needed?
comments.author: JUAUDE

comments.text: I was also worried about this, but it seems to have no problems.  The heat generated by those boards seems to be very minimal compared to the much larger heat source of the bed next to it, and the slits and wire openings seem quite sufficient.  From watching the fairly normal resulting temperatures I think the board would have to be overly sensitive to temperature for a problem to arise.  Since there are some discount parts in there I suppose it's possible to get a bad batch, but I had asked around a bit and I couldn't find anyone who had heard of a problem with those boards overheating.

print_settings.Notes:: https://github.com/fablabnbg/tinyboy/tree/master/cura

title: Electric unicycle headlight mount (Ninebot One trolley handle, Lampenhalter)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Ninebot One electric unicycle is equipped with a Trolley-Handle as found e.g. in http://g02.a.alicdn.com/kf/HTB15Qs6JpXXXXb5XFXXq6xXFXXX5/201283143/HTB15Qs6JpXXXXb5XFXXq6xXFXXX5.jpg

The Trolley handle (if mounted front, not rear...) can be used to mount a headlight.

In addition to the recommended rubber mount design, there are two earlier alternate approches shown here:

  • The part with the three large holes printed in black secures a headlight using its normal strap wrapped twice to reduce the needed diameter.

  • The part printed in gray replaces the normal strap and is perfectly suited for this kind of headlight "V-SAV": https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/81GgDvzfwdL._SL1500_.jpg

The smaller part printed in black is the most elegant and durable design. It requires flexible TPU rubber filament to print so that you can insert the lamp into the pocket. (I crashed all the other designs, but with this one, there is almost no chance to break anything). The filament used is black flexible TPU from sainsmart. 210°C with slow 25mm/sec.

The design encapsulates the lamp only. Remove the adjustable plate from the back of the lamp.
To adjust the angle, I simply wedge extra material into the top or bottom. the foto shows and earlier version with ony 3 deg downwards tilt. the final design has 10 deg, which appears to be just right for the way a ninebot one positions its trolley handle.

There is also an adapter for mounting things at the rear: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1734589

Printer:

Tinyboy Fabricator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

The final version was printed with TPU rubber filament.
Orientation was face down, with 15% zigzag support (touching base) carrying the 'ceiling' of the pocket, and reaching through the central hole to support (portions of) the upper side of the eliptical ring.

Machine parameters for cura 2.1.2 were
0.2mm layers, 0.8mm shell, 35% infill triangles, 25mm/sec, 210°C, 110% flow.

My settings for using a TinyBoy with Cura 2.1.2 are at https://github.com/fablabnbg/tinyboy/tree/master/cura

Removing Support

The TPU rubber filament strongly sticks to itself. (It is not the best support material, but on a single nozzle printer I have no choice.)

Zigzag support walls can be removed with almost no tools, by applying manual force. As soon as you can tear away one wall, the rest follows, as they are all connected.

That leaves a rugged surface behind, but with the face down orientation, those surfaces are not visible later. A sharp pair of pliers was used to remove some nasty bits and some stringing.

title: Lulzbot Extruder Idler Block for Greg/Wade style extruders - Heatset Insert Edition

description.text:
I really like the greg/wade style extruders overall, and the lulzbot variant is the best one out there of that type. That being said, I hate, loath and otherwise utterly dispise the stupid idler arm itself for one reason. Every time I need to remove the damned thing, the stupid internal M3 nut spins inside and strips it out. Literally every time. I've killed more idler latches over my 3d printing time just by doing that simple operation. So, after i broke my 10 billionth idler latch today, I decided to fix it. All that stupid nut does is hold the M3 bolt in place. Why not replace it with a heat set insert? It will actually strengthen the part at that point, and it won't strip inside!

So here it is

This is based off the latest 1.4c lulzbot variant, licensing is Creative Commons Open Source Attribution as usual. Please feel free to use this part in any manner you see fit. If I can save one person from the agony of a stripped idler arm nut socket, then it will all be worth it.

Instructions: insert one M3 heat set insert (http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a331/=13ettuz) into the hole in the side of the idler. Then install it using the stock mounting hardware and bearing insert thingy in the stock locations.

This will fit any of the Lulzbot extruders, for all the AO-10x variants, the Taz variants 1-6, and the Lulzbot Mini. it should also fit most other Greg/Wade style extruders

Edit: If your existing idler bolt does NOT have threads all the way up, you may need to replace it with a new 25mm long M3 Cap head bolt. You can find them here: https://www.amazon.com/M3x25mm-Screw-Socket-Screws-100Pcs/dp/B0143GZQNW/ref=sr_1_1?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1469314964&sr=1-1&keywords=m3+bolt+25mm

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.50mm nozzle

Infill:

85% or better

Notes:

This is an extruder part, ABS or similar material is warranted due to heat exposure

description.text: When I tried printing the quarter model this one is derived from, none of the surface geometry was printed, even when sliced at 0.1mm resolution. This model trades off absolute accuracy in favor of printability by slightly increasing the feature height.

Recommended Slic3r settings are:
-Set printer settings to lift z slightly (0.2mm) during retraction.
-All layer heights 0.1mm (even first layer).
-Fill density: 1
-Fill pattern: concentric
-Top/bottom fill pattern: concentric.
-Infill density: 1

title: Wanhao i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create Titan Extuder mounting plate

description.text:
Update (7/31): Achoo01 and I talked on reddit and he found me on here and gave me an idea about improving the Titan mounting plate. It'll either be a version 2 of the mounting plate or a legit X carriage, so stay tuned for more.

Update (7/27): Fully updated version that uses M4 button head screws.

Update (7/27): After much consideration I have decided ton redesign the mounting plate so it'll use button head hex screws instead of socket cap hex screws because buttoned head heads are smaller than socket caps and will allow for more area to be gripped by the screw. I'll boil it down for you. The mounting olate itself is 7.5mm thick, M4 socket cap heads are 4mm tall meaning (I made the counter sink hole the same height) you'll only get about 3mm actual mounting with the M4 screws. As for button head screws the head is about 2.2mm tall (I rounded it off to 2.5mm when redesigning the countersink hole depth) so now you'll have 4.5mm of plate gripping the screw. I'd recommend you use M4 button heads a that are 12mm ifor you're using the stock metal bearing blocks screw which will give you 7.5mm of screw grip into the bearing blocks, but if you're using 3D printed bearing blocks the the ones designed by user thustvedt I'd recommend something like 16mm in length which will give you a longer 11.5mm screw grip into the 3D printed bearing block but if you want to use the 12mm button heads I won't stop you but I do worry you'll get a lesser stronger bond. I'll post the newer mounting plate later on tonight because as if right now I am on the road heading to a vacationdestination, but I thought I'd update this page I'm out on the open road.

Update (7-25): I fixed some minor mistakes on the mounting plate so if so please get the new and improved version! Also there's not a lot of space to put in a print cooling mod, so I'm currently creating my own. I'll release it within a week.

So I wanted a Titan + E3D V6 on my Wanhao i3 but couldn't seem to find a mount for it (except for an eerily similar Titan mount for the Zonestar P802M, but it should be noted that I did not remix this from that) so I came up with my own. It is now designed for the used of M4 button head screws (I originally designed it to use socket head screws). Now if you leave your Wanhao i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create as is this Titan mount will crash into the top bar thingy so be sure to use the 3rd-rail Z tower brace created by user delukart. That's all I have, have a nice day and happy printing!

PS: I used some random titan spacer I found on here, but I can't remember who made it so I'm sorry to whoever made it I can't give you credit. Big shout out to you for sure, and if I ever remember who you were I'll be sure to credit you.

PSS: You can use the stock extruder motor for this set up, but it'll crash into the other side of the X axis and you'll lose X length, so I highly recommend you a 18Ncm NEMA 17 pancake motor which can plug into the stock extruder plugin and you don't have to do any wire replacing. If you want less power like some Titan users do you could use a 13Ncm NEMA 17 pancake motor but I do not (emphasis on not) recommend doing that because the 13Ncm version doesn't have a plugin but rather the wires are just wired directly into the motor meaning you'll have to totally replace the printer's extruder wires which I don't want to do, but hey whatever salts your soup.

[Links]

Titan dummy model I used when making it: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1514324

Wanhao bearing block i used when desinging this. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1172838

3rd-rail Z tower brace: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1454073

18Ncm NEMA 17 Pancake Motor: http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/nema-17-bipolar-step-motor-29v-07a-18ncm255ozin-17hs100704s-p-260.html

13Ncm NEMA 17 Pancake Motor: http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/nema-17-bipolar-step-motor-35v-1a-13ncm184ozin-17hs081004s-p-101.html

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

Anything above 50%

Notes:

Use a strong filament. I'll personally be using PETG, but ABS could work. If you want to be all fancy shmancy you could go with carbon fiber PLA or polycarbonate of you can push your Wanhao i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create to do so.

Now as I said I haven't gone through with the full Titan conversion yet but I'll be going about it like this.

Things you'll need

● A Titan Extruder
● An E3D V6 hotend
● Either the stock extruder motor or a 13Ncm/18Ncm NEMA 17 stepper motor (I highly reccomend you use a 18Ncm NEMA 17 pancake motor out of all of these options)
● The 3rd rail tower brace mod made by user delukart
● 12 M4 button head hex screws 12mm 16mm long
● The 2 stock Wanhao drag chains that house the wires
● The stock hex flat head screw that attacks the drag chain onto the hotend mounting plate.
● The three stock X axis bearing blocks (or you can substitute three 3D printed stock bearing blocks)
● Time and effort

Optional step: 3D print off 3 bearing blocks for the x axis (I have them linked because I used it while I was designing my plate)

Step 1: Print off and install the 3rd rail tower brace mod and intall it onto your Wanhao i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create

Step 2: Print off Titan plate using a strong plastic such as ABS or PETG with and infill of 50% or above (me personally I'll be using 60%).

Step 3: Remove everything from X axis. Meaning unplug everything. The thermistor, the fans, unscrew the extruder from its mount, out the hotend, take out the heater cartridge if you can, strip it all down until it's just the steel mounting plate thingy that mounts the hotend.

Step 4: Remove the old hotend mounting plate.

Step 5: Remove the bearing blocks from the x axis. This will involve removing the smooth rods so set the two smooth rods aside for later.

Step 6: Using the 12mm/16mm long button head hex screws screw the mounting plate onto the bearing blocks.

Step 7: Take the Titan extruder and the Nema 17 pancake motor and attach them onto the mounting plate. The motor should be on the right side.

Step 8: Attach E3D V6 into Titan extruder

Step 9: (optional but it'll help you skip step 10). Attach a female header onto the stock hotendrag wire, and a male connector onto the E3D V6 hotend wire. This will save you from fishing the hotend wires through the drag chains (note I thing they're called female and male connectors, I'm still getting new to the whole electrical world)

Step 9.5: Make the wire lengths shorter for the thermistor because you'll be plugging into the stock thermistor plug later on and don't need to plug it all the way into the board.

Step 10: (This is only if you didn't do/want to do step 9. Me personally I'll be doing this because I want thicker wires taking on the hotend electrical current): Fish the E3D V6 hotend wire through the drag chains. I've been told you can use the stock plugin for the NEMA 17 extruder motor on a NEMA 17 pancake motor so no need to fish newer motor wires through the drag chains (unless you want to).

Step 11: Attach the X axis smooth rods that were removed in step 5 back into the bearings, and attach them onto the x axis (make sure you don't attach the whole thing upside down lol).

Step 12: Attach the drag chain onto the mounting plate with the stock m3 flat head screw.

Step 13: Plug everything into their appropriate plug-ins (the thermistor is the the thermistor plugin, the hotend wire is in the hotend plugin if you did step 8, the heatbreak fan is plugged in, and the NEMA 17 pancake is plugged in as well). Once that's one make sure the hotend and extruder works properly.

Step 14: Take your current e-steps per mm value (on the Wanhao i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create it's 96) and multiply it by 3.58 to get the new e-steps per mm value (if you have it to 96 it's 350.84). Full credit goes to Ultimaker forum user Marcel2016 for calculating the Titan extruder multiplier, if you're you're there bug thank you my friend (link to the forum post: https://ultimaker.com/en/community/21029-e3d-titan-extruder-firmware-settings )

Step 15: Level the bed.

Step 16: (optional): Print off a calibration test or two to make sure everything is running properly.

Step 18: CONGRATULATIONS! You've successfully converted Wanhao i3/Maker Select/Cocoon Create to a Titan extruder. Give yourself a big pat on the back!

title: Anker PowerCore 10.000 mAh - bike holder (+ CAD-files)

description.text:
Because using my phone while riding the bike (e.g.: navigation or Pokémon Go) needs a huge amount of battery, I decided to buy an external battery pack and to design a holder for my mountain bike.
It suits for the Anker PowerCore 10.000 mAh but I also added the CAD-files, so you can customize it yourself for other power packs.

Dimensions for the power pack:
width = 63 mm
thickness = 23 mm
height (until 1. LED) = 70 mm

I am also using this bike mount for my Samsung Galaxy S3 where I added a small hole for the charger:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52901

It should perfectly fit under the stem ("Vorbau" in german !?) with a diameter of 36 mm.

For assembling you will need:
4x M3 bolts with a minimum length of 15 mm
4x M3 nuts.

Maybe the third hole isn't necessary, but I added it for safety reasons.

The 4 LEDs which indicate the power level are still visible upon the upper edge.

26.07.2016: I printed & tested it on my bike an it fits perfectly without any kind of rubber between the 2 parts. Also the power pack has little free space.

title: WeMos D1 Mini ESP8266 LED Bar Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a case designed to hold a WeMos D1 Mini ESP8266 microcontroller and a strip of addressable LEDs. The ESP8266 can connect to a data source and display status on the LEDs. I use it to read out the status of my garage door and other sensors in my home. The ESP8266 connects to an MQTT message broker and receives messages to control the LEDs.

I printed the body in black ABS and the lens in clear ABS. Other materials would work well. The lens doesn't have to be clear. The LEDs are very bright and will be easily visible through white material. Other colors will also work, but will filter the color of the LEDs.

The WeMos D1 Mini is a self-contained ESP8266 board with the ESP-12F microcontroller, a 3.3v regulator and built-in USB UART. They are readily available from a variety of sources. Official WeMos Store

I used five WS2812b LEDs cut from a strip containing 60 LEDs per meter. These are also available all over eBay. Find WS2812b LED strips on eBay

You can also purchase WS2812b LED strips at Amazon.

You can see in the photos that I added an additional SMT chip onto the microcontroller. This is a schmidt-trigger hex inverter used to convert the 3.3V output of the microcontroller to the 5V input of the LED strip. This is not necessarily needed. In most cases, the 3.3V output will drive the LEDs just fine. I just wanted to try the proper level converter to see if I could make it work.

Demo video here: https://youtu.be/nMmwOEkX5Ko

When you click on these links and make a purchase, it can result in commissions from eBay, Amazon and Alibaba that help support my work.

Printer:

MakerFarm Prusa i3v

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Supports are necessary to print the raised lip on the body pieces.

Print Cleanup

Depending on your printer and slicer, the support material may leave a rough surface on the lips of the body that fit into the lens. After printing and removing the support material, you can sand or file down the rough surfaces so the lens fits correctly. The rough surfaces will be covered by the lens and will not be visible.

Gluing The Case Together

I glued my case together using Testors Plastic Cement, available from Amazon.

After dry-fitting everything to make sure it fit, I disassembled it and brushed liquid cement onto the mating edges of the case. I let it sit for about 30 seconds and then assembled it. I also brushed cement on the front lips of the body and the mating surfaces inside the lens and pressed the lens on.

I bound the parts together using zip ties and a vise and let the cement set for about 30 minutes.

The vise I used is a Panavise Jr. I also used it to hold the parts while soldering.

Fusion 360 Model

This was designed using Fusion 360. You can get the original design files here: http://a360.co/2aiOI76

Code

Here is a NodeMCU script to exercise the LEDs:

local NUM_LEDS = 5;
local i = 1;
local d = 1;
local hue = 0;

local function hueToRgb(hue)
    if hue >=0 and hue < 60  then return 255, hue * 255 / 60, 0 end;
    if hue >=60 and hue < 120  then return (120-hue) * 255 / 60, 255, 0 end;
    if hue >=120 and hue < 180  then return 0, 255, (hue-120) * 255 / 60 end;
    if hue >=180 and hue < 240  then return 0, (240-hue) * 255 / 60, 255 end;
    if hue >=240 and hue < 300  then return (hue-240) * 255 / 60, 0, 255 end;
    if hue >=300 and hue < 360  then return 255,0,(360-hue) * 255 / 60 end;
end

ws2812.init()
local buffer = ws2812.newBuffer(NUM_LEDS,3);
buffer:fill(0,0,0);

tmr.alarm(0, 50, 1, function()
    hue = (hue + 1) % 360;
    local r,g,b = hueToRgb(hue);

    i = i + d;
    if( i == NUM_LEDS ) then d = -1 end
    if( i == 1 ) then d = 1 end
    buffer:fade(3);
    buffer:set(i, r,g,b);
    buffer:write();
end)

description.text:
This is a water bottle tote that attaches to your belt loop. I got tired of hand carrying the bottles or putting them in the pockets of my cargo pants so I came up with this simple design. It prints in two parts, attached using acetone (nail polish remover). I added a ring from a key ring and a simple carabiner clip.

8/2/16 - posted final 2.0 design. Removed older stl files. Smaller shaft proved too fragile so I am only posting the stronger version now.

NOTE: Not all water bottles are created equally. I found that the bottles from Costco (Kirkland brand) are slightly larger at the base and do not slide in easily. The inner diameter is 67mm (~2.64 inches). You may want to scale the stl file up a percent or two to make it more universal.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The base requires no supports. The top portion needs a support or two for the arch where the ring attaches. It can be printed at 15-20% infill but I prefer to go up to at least 50% for added strength. The lower the infill, the more fragile the long shaft will be. .

Print the two parts. Wipe the inside opening on the top portion with acetone, and wipe (or dip ) the top of the rod for the lower portion in acetone and press together. Wipe additional acetone on top of and below the two pieces and hold until set. Run ring through the hoop and connect the carabiner clip. Attach top belt and walk around town with hands free water bottles. :)

description.text: Joined two things with OpenSCAD.
This lesson is an introduction to Tinkercad, 3D printing, and building classroom community through the creation of a personalized classroom rubik’s cube.

Printer Brand:

3D Systems

Printer:

Cube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Students will be working in teams to generate a 9 letter word or word with a combination of symbols to represent the chosen topic.
Students will be working collaboratively in Tinkercad using a pre-made base to add the letters of the chosen word.

Building classroom community and social and emotional learning through which learners acquire and effectively apply the knowledge, attitudes, and skills necessary to understand and manage emotions, set and achieve positive goals, feel and show empathy for others, establish and maintain positive relationships, and make responsible decisions. This lesson helps reinforce four of seven strategies for building positive classrooms:
Make Learning Relevant
Create a Classroom Code of Conduct
Teach Positive Actions
Reinforce Positive Behaviors
http://www.ascd.org/publications/educational-leadership/sept08/vol66/num01/Seven-Strategies-for-Building-Positive-Classrooms.aspx

Lesson - Part 1: Brainstorm and Share Out Duration: Approximately 30 Minutes Share example of final product (image) so that students understand what they are designing to represent their classroom or selected topic. Divide students into six random groups. As a team, students will have 10-15 minutes to generate as many nine letter words or a combination with symbols that represent the topic on the chart paper or collaborative document. The desire is to not repeat words which is why the group share out is important. Highlight which words are being repeated and then after each group has shared out, have each group select a word that they are going to create. Lesson - Part 2: Importing an Image into Tinkercad Duration: Approximately 10-15 Minutes Tinkercad allows the import of either an .svg or .stl file. An .svg file can be a converted .jpg or .png file. I use the following .svg converter - http://picsvg.com/ An .stl file is any file that has been created for 3D printing. This import ability allows the designer to import any 3D design and rework it or build upon it. In this project, you can use the .stl to build the final pieces. Lesson - Part 3: Creating with Tinkercad Duration: Varies by level This is the step where differentiation should occur based on your knowledge of your students. For younger students or students who have never used Tinkercad:
Using the attached generic .stl file, students can import the basic foundation of the project into Tinkercad and drag and drop the letters of the word on the tiles. Tinkercad is not a collaborative application but for this part, each student or pair of students could do the word to be introduced to how Tinkercad works. For older students or students who have used Tinkercad:
Students can measure the squares of the Rubik’s cube and design from the beginning. Tinkercad is not a collaborative application but for this part, each student or pair of students could do the word to be introduced to how Tinkercad works. For an even more advanced level of using Tinkercad:
Students can use one image instead of individual letters that cover a full 9 block section. (See attached images provided by Drew Lentz) Finished Example Advanced Design Lesson - Part 4: Exporting and Printing the Design Duration: 45 minutes per 9 piece side. Students will need to export the design for 3D printing from Tinkercad as an .stl file and share it with the teacher for final printing. Printing will take approximately 45 minutes per 9 letter section.
Rafts: no
Supports: no
Resolution: 0.2 mm
Infill: 10% Lesson - Part 5: Adding the Design to the Rubik's Cube Dueration: Approximately 15 minutes to apply and an hour to dry Use Gorilla Glue to apply each piece to the Rubik’s Cube by moistening the two sides that will be adhering together. Use very little glue as it expands. It will take about an hour per side for the glue to dry and adhere permanently. Do not speed up this process as it will result in pieces moving and sliding.

Chart Paper and markers or Collaborative Google Doc for each group
Computers for Tinkercad
.STL file
Standard Rubik’s cube (six sides with 9 squares on each side)
Gorilla glue
6 filament colors (preference of red, blue, green, yellow, orange, and white)

• Collaboration
  • Teamwork
  • 3D Printing
  • 3D Design
The assessment should occur before sending the word to be printed.

I didn't find a 25 degree mount, so I made a customizable angle mount. Set the angle, and then play with the other two parameters to get your camera where you want it.

Here's a video ! It's a BEAST !!!!

https://youtu.be/vUQuWEgAX-o

I had some left over ABS and PETG plastic that I used to print my handle. I suggest PETG. It's the most durable. I used one momentary switch and one on-off toggle switch. I used two 18650 batteries in series and 3D printed these great battery cases to slip in the PVC tube:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900

The switches are wired to connect the negative wires. The toggle switch is a "Safety Switch" it's connected to the negative wire of the batteries and one post on the Push Button Momentary switch. Once the push button switch is engaged it connects the negative wire of the battery to the negative wire of the "spark" unit and BANG. The positive wires of the battery to the "spark" unit are permanently connected.

I glued the handle together with hot glue and used beads of glue to wedge the handle into the PVC tube. The batteries don't wear out when not using it. When they finally do need charging all you have to do is charge them. I haven't gotten to that point yet.

Great protection on trails where stray dogs may be encountered. Cheap and easy to make.

description.text:
honeybee - 75mm brushed pico quad frame.

  • 3.5 grams
  • 45mm props
  • 6x15mm motors (recommend micro motor warehouse 'fast')
  • micro scisky FC
  • batteries supported:
    • mylipo.de 205mah 25-50c 1s
    • newbeedrone 210mah 30-60c 1s
    • turnigy nano-tech 300mah 45-90c 1s

I used these "White Rubber 5mm Open Hole Ring Dual Side Cable Wiring Grommet" grommets for the motors. They're cheaper and considerably lighter than black rubber grommets from my local hardware store.

I've been flying an inductrix/tiny whoop and wanted something that could be pushed a little harder, this is the result. I'm using props from a crazyflie but if you search aliexpress for 45mm propellers there's a bunch. Please let me know if you build one, I am still real new to this and working on tuning my PIDs and learning to fly.

Printing this in alloy 910 results in a very crash-survivable quadcopter. it's a little flexible and super light coming in at under 22 grams fully built, including the 210mah battery.

title: Olympia Drip Tray Cremina Express Coffex Maximatic Livietta

description.text:
This is my first Maker project. I had help with this from folks at my university. It printed up great for me. I hope that this helps others!

This is a replacement drip tray for an Olympia espresso machine (Cremina, Coffex, or Maximatic) or a Pasquini Livietta (which is the rebranded Olympia).

I found it necessary to trim a few millimeters off of the top "wings" where they meet the espresso machine body (so, the "back" when looking at the machine from the front). You might need to trim it down a tiny bit and you might want to sand it a bit to get it to fit, but, the trimming was truly minimal (took me about 5 minutes to do it).

From the photos, the grey drip tray is the one that I printed (the black one is the original that I measured for correct proportions). The first three photos show 1) how the final printed tray looked from the top, 2) the grey (printed) and black (original) from the bottom, 3) the grey (printed) and black (original) from the top. The fourth photo shows the grey (printed) drip tray fitted into my Pasquini Livietta. The fifth and sixth photos show where I needed to cut off a few millimeters of plastic from the end wings so it would fit into the metal frame. The seventh photo shows how the original metal grate fits perfectly into the grey (printed) drip tray.

author: SavageWarlord

description.text: Sized slightly larger so the ball bearing rotates freely. Footprint is the same, requires no modification to chassis holes.

This is based on the Sparkfun Pokedex battery phone case project.

EDIT December 14, 2016:
Added the Lavender Town repair ticket in both pdf and svg (for editing), as well as my modified weakness chart.

EDIT August 20, 2016:
Just found out that SE and 5 are the same size, so in theory it's compatible. That's kind of a relief, I was worried this was obsolete.

===

BETA NOTES/ISSUES:
First print through on my TAZ5 with n-vent copolyester:

  • Minor warping issues, probably need to adjust heat
  • Excessive bridging inside (needs thorough cleaning out before phone will fit)
  • Sagging on the top entrance, makes the phone too thick to enter, just need to counter bridge in the file
  • LED holes too small, probably due to printing (just need drilling)
  • Hole for the dome light sealed up
  • Doesn't quite fit all the way to the bottom, probably due to sagging. May need some adjusting, be it bringing the face up or expanding the slot.
  • Bottom (back face with vent) completely sealed up(except the vents, those are fine)!!! Possibly because brim?? Made clean back which is nice and finished, but now it's a gigantic hassle to put in the electronics.
  • Hinges turned out subpar, probably due to several factors. I imagine a better printer or some support would fix this. Currently being held on with red tape.
  • Sanding turned into a huge ugly mess, ended up covering the face with vinyl. If left alone or resin coated next time it will probably turn out O.K.
  • Borrowed some decor ideas from the Sparkfun, I thought the repair ticket was a super cool idea as well as the weakness chart.
  • Adding a swipe guide plate will be really easy if these hinges end up working out, plenty of room.

===

Had this idea almost immediately after the game came out, but didn't get around to it. Someone else made a parametric version, but haven't released the files, so I figured I may as well just go ahead and modify for my obsolete brick.

I also poked a hole for the light-up dome thing by the LEDs, since I happen to have a bunch of incidentally perfect ones lying around.

In the future, I intend to make a little swing plate for the front so I can get perfect throws without trying. Possibly a way to do it with curveballs?

Next on the list: reverse engineer the PKMNGo Plus???

description.text:
An interchangeable Extruder Die system, designed to fit a NorthStar Clay Extruder.

Die Base dimensions - 110 x 110 x 11mm, fitting inside a chamber about 89mm across (3.5 inches)

Printed in PLA - Base at 20% infill, inset at 25%

To suspend the inside part of the die, use two 1/4 x 4 inch bolts. Before inserting bolts, drill out the holes in the base and the inset part with a 1/4 drill bit. This gives a tight fit for the holes, keeping the die inset from moving around while extruding.

To create your own inset die, use the Inset Template file, or modify the file on TinkerCAD:

Here are some of the other dies in process on TinkerCAD (not yet tested): Die Variations

If you make something with it, please post a picture, and let me know how it works. Thanks!

Printer:

Oni H-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20 for Base, 25-30 for Inset

Notes:

For Printing, it is a good idea to print the Die parts upside-down. this maintains a clear, sharp edge at the bottom of the die. If printed down, this edge requires cleaning and lose its edge.

This is part of ongoing research to explore ways of using 3D printing with ceramic media. After initially designing a few dies that were solid 3D printed parts, this design was intended to reduce the time and material it would take to make a new die.

The parts were designed initially in Rhino, and then recreated in TinkerCAD

description.text:
The bees are in trouble. Toxic chemicals, diseases, and a decrease in suitable habitat threaten their existence more and more. There are many types of bees, of which the honey bee is the most well-known. But did you know there are many other species that live in solitary? They don't have a beehive and live in their own little hole in a piece of wood, stone, or earth. Depending on their size, they want tunnels between 3 and 10mm in diameter, with a length up to 150mm. They use it throughout the seasons: hibernation in winter, shelter in autumn, nursery in summer and spring.

Bees are essential for a healthy world. They keep the flora diverse and they increase the size and number of fruit and vegetable harvests. Completely harmless to humans, these happy little buzzers make the world a better place.Will you give them some shelter, and play your part in a better world?

Hang it up a few mm away from the wall, so it slants slightly in a downward angle. This way, any rain will flow out rather than in.
If you make one, please share the results!

Bowls and Ornaments based on solutions to the Thomson electron problem.
see - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomson_problem
and - http://www-wales.ch.cam.ac.uk/~wales/CCD/Thomson/table.html
Circles were added to a sphere at points corresponding to the positions calculated for electrons as solutions to the Thomson problem. The openSCAD code includes other attempts to make attractive bowls and can be used to transfer objects centered on the xy plane to the surface of a sphere.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Hexagons were used to cover the surface of bowl_612.stl. Hexagons cannot uniformly cover a sphere and there are faults in the pattern. A close look shows small holes, kites etc., surrounded by 5 hexagons. There are 12 such faults over the sphere; they occur at positions that approximate the vertices of an icosahedron or the faces of a dodecahedron. Five such "faults" are visible on bowl_612.stl - an image of one is below. The Voronoi image, see the table of solutions referenced above, shows a similar effect.

description.text:
This is a scan of a wood/cork Anri Carving. They are mostly used as bottle stoppers. This one is scanned and made to stand-alone by adding a torus or two with .Mesh Magic To use it as a bottle stopper,set Slic3r or equivalent to sink the stand and 'cork area' so it's under the print surface. Using Cura, cut off approx. 33mm.

Once printed I use hot glue to attach a natural or artificial cork to it. I use just enough to extend out of the joint all the way around., Peel the excess of later on. The hot glue Works great.

A very simple arduino based step-sequencer for modular synthesizers. This is a work in progress. It does work in it's current state, but there are some more features i want to include (e.g. the brain-switch doesn't do anything yet :) ) What it does:
On each pulse to the CLK-input, the sequencer will advance one step and output a voltage based on the position of the potentiometer of the current step to the output of each row. There are two independent sequencers that can be clocked independently. Each sequencer has two rows of potentiometers and three outputs. Each row has its own individual output and can thus be used as an individual 8 step sequencer, but there is a third output for each sequencer that will alternate between the voltage from the first and the second row every 8 steps, thus concatenating both rows together to form a 16 step sequencer. What it will do at some point:
Right now, the arduino is a bit superfluous. While it is needed for the routing, it could be easily replaced by a clocking circuit. The plan is to connect the brain switch to the arduino and thus give the sequencer two modes: One in which it functions just as described above (brain off) and one in which it can be controlled via usb to enable different sequencing patterns, address single steps and synchronize it to a DAW. The only thing missing for that is the extra code for the arduino as well as the software for communication on the pc.

I've used a lasercutter to cut and engrave the front plate. Please note that this project only includes the front plate - I've used an enclosure from conrad for the rest (see http://www.conrad.de/ce/de/product/520780/PULTGEHAeUSE-HIT-PULT/0203053 ) It shouldn't be too hard to customize this in order to work with any enclosure you build yourself, though. Parts list:
  • 1 arduino
  • 2x AD 420 AR
  • 2x 74HC4067
  • 4x 74HC595
  • 32x 10k lin. potentiometers
  • 32x knobs for the potentiometers
  • 34x LEDs + LED-sockets (3mm)
  • 1 2A/250V flip switch
  • 10 3.5mm audio jack sockets

description.text:
This part is a cosmetic upgrade I wanted to do some kind of upgrades for this
micro helicopter but there were no such parts that I know of but I want to

So I decided to design a custom fin to replace the stock one on this micro helicopter
to make it look better. And the new 3-D printed fin did not have much affect on its
function. If you decide to download this file and have this part 3-D printed out I
recommend you use superglue to fill in the gap inside the square hole where the tail
boom is inserted because the square hole is a bit wider with the help of the superglue
it will fill in the gap between the square hole in the fin and the tail boom to adjust
the space so the new 3-D printed fin will in fit well without it coming off if you want
to you can gule it on it does not make any difference.

This is an outlet clip to hold a 120v outlet to a fiberglass wall. These outlets are generally used on boats, motor-homes, travel trailers, recreational vehicles, etc

title: Amazon Echo Dot Acoustic Stand!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Having several Amazon Echo Dots around the house has been cool and while the tiny speaker isn't up to the audio quality of its bigger sibling. They are adequate for task at hand, however since it is located at the bottom on the unit facing down they can be hard to hear and sitting on a nightstand or table with other objects around can make this a problem. So I designed an "acoustic horn" which elevates the Amazon Echo Dot up off the table and reflects the sound into the room rather than onto the table. Also if you want to see more about this build, check out the YouTube here ( https://youtu.be/7Zorggq4Oqw ) to see more!

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our one of a kind swag shop for yourself a Maker Geek friend at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

Printer:

Just Any Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 (or better)

20% to 40% As needed...

Notes:

This should print well with basic setting, however because of the "fingers" at the top top suggest using 0.2 layer height max. Also if printing in ABS, do suggest using a brim to hold down as there is minimized surface area.

comments.text: I find that when printing this with PLA (in CURA) with an low infill of ~20% w 2 walls the "4 arms" are very weak (snapping off with a light touch), and I'd really hate to waste more than 20% on infill for a holder.  Maybe some thoughts about increasing the structure for the arms? Otherwise this fits my echo 2 just fine and the rest of the structure is solid just weakness in the arm areas.

remixed_from.title: Spool Roller for Folger Tech 2020 i3

description.text:
At last some mods to address "bugs".

  1. Old design wrapped around top rail and would cause interference with the print head if you actually print something all the way as tall as your printer allows.

  2. Split, mushroom-head bearing axles were snapping left and right.

Both issues addressed. A new mounting foot that friction-fits right into the center channel on top of the top rail, no wraparound. And new axles and keepers. HOWEVER, the axles, on my printer, were a tight friction fit for the 608 bearings and I didn't have to try the fragile little keepers... plus, my "rig" ain't so good on the precise nature of fitting one part into another perfectly.

Additionally, this version is a little lower profile for all around plastic savings, still plenty sturdy. For me.

Pics don't have the same, generic "speed holes" as the STL file, but y'all can figure that out.

Finally, I am no sketchup expert, which is what I did this in. There are a couple of botched up places in the file on a couple of corners and edges. However, it's solid and prints fine. For me.

remixed_from.title: OpenSCad Stencil Font for Write library

description.text:
After regularly loosing luggage labels or the written contents inside, this is my suggestion for improvement.
It is not unlosable but attached with a cable tie it should withstand most things that happen to luggage.
It also makes your luggage easier to detect on the belt when printed in conspicious color.
Readability is good with the font sufficiently large and especially with backlighting (see image). Customization is through the OpenSCAD-File and there are three principle options to choose from:
(1) Engraved text (as shown in the images)
(2) Engraved text as hollow area inside the label (aka hidden) (no image shown)
(3) Embossed (no image shown) The size of the label is automatically adjusted depending on text length, number of lines and fontsize. Hidden text can only be seen in backlight so is more "secure". It needs write.scad:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193
and stencil2.dxf:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:100779 2013-11-01; Changed name from Customizable to Parametric luggage label.
See also the new Customizer-version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:175150

It printed nicely with 1 shell, 3 bottom and top layers and 25% infill.
Do not make the fontsize to small otherwise letters will loose details at least when engraving. With engraved text it can be printed upside down as well (text at bottom) if you prefer the later top side to be smooth; nice when printing on glass.

description.text: A heightmap of New Zealand and it's submerged continental fragment Zealandia. The data is from the NIWA bathymetry map found here https://www.niwa.co.nz/our-science/oceans/bathymetry . I had to reduce the file size considerably which meant that the mountains (above sea level) lost a lot of definition. To combat that I replaced the mountains on the mainland with the other heightmap of New Zealand shown, which is from https://www.reddit.com/r/newzealand/comments/1c170r/grayscale_altitude_map_of_nz/?st=ir01jpe1&sh=655789be . Note for OpenSCAD users. I couldn't get Thingiverse to let the png image download fully so I have included a .obj file THE .OBJ FILE IS A RENAMED PNG, IT WILL NOT MAKE A 3D IMAGE. So if you're compiling from the .scad file just rename the .obj file with a .png suffix and that should work fine.

description.text:
For whatever reason the pulleys that come with Velleman VERTEX K8400 printer have very short thread that is easy to damage. Instead of replacing entire pulley and facing the same problem again, I came up with this simple solution. 3d printed ring with much longer thread is placed over the pulley. Mounting screw holds on the thread in the ring and passes through the original hole in the pulley, which has to be slightly widened.

This ring was designed for K8400 printer's pulleys, which are mounted on 8mm rods. Since this is extremely simple thing, you can easily create your own ring matching the dimensions of your pulley.

UPDATE
Unfortunately this fix lasted just 2 months. Then the threads in the rings became loose. I printed rings with PLA and ABS may give the better result, however at this time I decided address the root of the problem by replacing rare 19T pulleys and GT2.5 belts used in VERTEX K8400 with much cheaper and widely used 20T pulleys with longer thread and GT2 belts. Waiting the parts to arrive. Will add another update here on whether the replacement was success.

UPDATE 2
I was able to successfully replace the pulleys and the belts. The details are here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1857266

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

VERTEX K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed rings with Brim, but they should stick without it as well.

Material: PLA

Assembly
  • Widen the holes in the pulley, make sure M3 screw can freely pass them.
  • Use M3 hex socket cup screw to cut the thread in the ring.
  • Place the ring over the pulley and align the holes.
  • Place the pulley with the ring on the rod and fix it in position using M3 4mm, or M3 5mm screw.

title: Drampa
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model definitely falls under a "passion project" for me. As soon as I saw Drampa in a reveal trailer a few weeks ago, I thought it would be quite the challenge to model it up from the few references available. Albeit, it's probably not 100% perfect to what the in-game model is, I'm still really glad with how it turned out.

Of course, knowing my luck, Pokemon will release an official figure of this guy come November ;)

I haven't been able to print it yet, but I split the model in half to make it an easier print. The whole model is intricate, so I thought spitting it would help save support material. However, I do have the whole STL model here in case you'd like to try the whole model.

The dimensions of the Drampa figure are 6.75"x 3"x 4.5". I figured being able to print the parts separately would also help if you want to scale up Drampa.

**11/29--I meant to share this months ago, but I was hesitant to share it. Now with the game out, I figured better now that never to share it! :D
Definitely sand down the tail to make it smoother. It comes off a little rigid in the file, which I was unable to fix in modeling.

As per my usual process with Pokemon models, I worked off images and screenshots of Drampa

title: Cane Holder w/ Belt Clip Version 1.3 Final

description.text:
1.0: I grew tired of constantly dropping my cane when having to use both my hands for something else, so I came up with this. The ID of the opening is 0.868" (22.04mm). If you would like a different size opening for other canes let me know the dimension and I'll release another version.

1.1: Made some minor adjustments to the clip angle, to make it easier attaching/releasing it from the belt. I made the outer radius smaller on the top of the clip, leaving more material making it a bit stronger, since it seemed to be a weak point.

1.2: Added notches on the cane holder, also added a securing strap. The strap should be printed with Ninja Flex.

1.3: So this is the final version of the cane holder, I'm pretty happy with the overall design, and how it works. I spent a lot of time testing the designs to get it perfect. I improved how the strap attaches to the holder, making it easier to use. The end without holes will need to be superglued into the slot on the holder itself(as shown in the first screenshot). I noticed the inside of the holder was becoming a bit loose after a while due to removing/attaching the cane holder. So I tightened the radius up a bit. You may have to grind out the inside to get the fit you like.
